title: Tele-dermatology of Skin Cancer: a Randomized Trial Comparing Remote Assessment With Conventional Visits in a Cohort of Local Health Authority Employees in the Province of Bergamo (the Shoot the Mole Study)
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to demonstrate the validity and utility of a tele-dermatology system in the midterm periodic screening of non-widespread skin lesions of recent onset or for which a specialized early classification is deemed to change the prognosis - including precancerous skin lesions as well as melanoma and non-melanoma skin cancers - compared to control visits at fixed follow-up.
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention described is a tele-dermatology system (a screening/remote-assessment procedure/device) for early detection and classification of skin lesions including melanoma and non-melanoma skin cancers, not a pharmacologic agent or biologic targeting Alzheimer pathology. Therefore it does not fit any of the Alzheimer-focused categories (disease-targeted biologic, disease-targeted small molecule, cognitive enhancer, or neuropsychiatric symptom improvement). citeturn0search0turn0search3

Act (key extracted details): Title = 'Tele-dermatology of Skin Cancer: a Randomized Trial ... (the Shoot the Mole Study)'; Registration NCT02902822; Intervention = Device/Procedure: Tele-dermatology (screening); Lead sponsor = Centro Studi GISED; Status = Completed. No drug or placebo is listed in the trial record. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Reflect: The trial objective is diagnostic/screening validation (compare remote assessment with conventional visits) and outcome measures relate to detection/agreement and incidence of suspicious lesions. This confirms the study is non-therapeutic (procedural/device/diagnostic) and therefore 'N/A' for the Alzheimer trial categories. citeturn0search2turn0search1
